talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: Under the provisions of the Therapeutic Substances Act and the National Health Act there is effective Commonwealth control of drugs as to labelling, assay standards, and suitability for use as advertised in relation to drugs which are pharmaceutical benefits. Drugs which are not pharmaceutical benefits, but which are imported or are the subject of interstate trade are subject to effective Commonwealth control in relation to standards (including labelling requirements) under the Therapeutic Substances Act. These Commonwealth controls supplement State Government controls over all those matters.

The Commonwealth Department of Health is continuously engaged in the assay of such preparations to ensure that standards are maintained, these assays being of preparations which are pharmaceutical benefits or are within the scope of the Therapeutic Substances Act.
The Commonwealth has power to prohibit the importation of drugs which are considered to be of a dangerous character.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: What is the underlying purpose of the National Health Act 1953-1961?
Is the cost of drugs used of prime consideration in the operation of the act?
Are all drugs available based on the most effective and safest preparations?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: The main purpose of the National Health Act is to provide medical, hospital and pharmaceutical benefits for persons who are receiving medical treatment. These benefits provide financial assistance for patients to help them meet the cost of medical and hospital treatment. The act also authorizes the arrangements between the Commonwealth and the medical profession for the provision of the pensioner medical service.
Drugs are made available as pharmaceutical benefits on the recommendation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee; cost is not the prime consideration in the committee's recommendations.
Yes.

No. On the contrary the present arrangement is beneficial to the majority of patients because it enables them to obtain, on payment of only 5s., drugs prescribed for them by their doctors from a very extensive range, including many drugs which are extremely costly.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Are the drugs, butazolidin, Chloromycetin and largactil available without restriction under the National Health Act 1953-1961?
If so, why?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: A chemist is not permitted to supply any drug as a pharmaceutical benefit unless he is presented with a prescription, written by a medical practitioner, for the supply of the drug to the patient. A medical practitioner may write a prescription for the supply of butazolidin as a pharmaceutical benefit if he considers that this drug would be appropriate for use in the treatment of the condition from which his patient is suffering. Chloromycetin may be prescribed as a pharmaceutical benefit only for the treatment of certain diseases specified in the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations, these restrictions being in accordance with recommendations by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. It is proposed that as from 1st May next largactil may be prescribed as a pharmaceutical benefit, only in approved hospitals, for patients discharged from hospital but still under psychiatric treatment and for pensioners - these restrictions being those recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.

talk.start.para: t asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Is he able to say whether many medical practitioners are forced, by economic pressure, to prescribe drugs on the pharmaceutical benefit list for the treatment of patients, although their medical judgment indicates that another drug, not on the list, would be more beneficial?

Do drugs listed as a pharmaceutical benefit cost a patient much less than a drug not listed?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply: -

item.label: 1 and 2.

Drugs listed as pharmaceutical benefits cost a patient 5s. for each prescription, unless the patient has a pensioner medical service entitlement card, in which case no charge is made. In most cases the 5s. charge is considerably less than the price that would be payable if the particular drug were not listed. There is a wide variation in the prices of drugs not listed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Social Services, upon notice -

item.para: Has the £200 property limitation, which applies when a pensioner has a weekly income of £3 10s., lost ils value over the years?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: In referring to the "£200 property limitation " I assume the honorable member has in mind the amount of property (after disregarding the home, &c.) which is not taken into account in the calculation of the rate of age or invalid pension or class B widow's pension payable under the means test. This is commonly referred to as the " property exemption ". The property exemption was £200 prior to the introduction of the merged means test in March, 1961, and this remains the effective figure where the pensioner's annual rate of income is £182 or more. However, where the annual rate of income is less than £182, the effective property exemption under the merged means test varies according to the annual rate of income. For each £1 by which the pensioner's annual rate of income falls short of £182, the property exemption rises by £10. Thus, the effective property exemption for a pensioner with no income is now £2,020.
Any question of liberalizations in the pensions means test will be considered when social services are reviewed in connexion with the preparation of the Budget later in the year.

I am not aware of any anomaly.
